description.narrative: Supporting Public Administration Reform (PAR) in Georgia-Together with partners, UNDP assists the Government of Georgia in steering and successful implementation of the Public Administration Reform (PAR).

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

comment.narrative:
1.1. Further enhance the capacities of the policy units in line ministries to produce high quality policy documents for internal use (such as policy briefs, white and green papers, policy papers and alike) 1.2. Provide coaching and consultancy to target ministries in development of organizational or sectorial strategies and their action plans in line with the new policy methodological guidelines. 1.3. Support finalization of government-wide electronic Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) System
2.1. Support Civil Service Bureau (CSB) in establishment of the Network of Civil Servants offering a forum space and encouragement of the professional and innovative civil service, through building capacities of managers in efficient management and leadership 2.2. Support CSB in improving the existing Electronic System for Human Resource Management (e-HRMS) including the creation and integration of a new module on performance appraisal and a module on professional development for civil servants 2.3. Continue increasing awareness on availability of accredited programs 2.4. Further support HRs, selected ministries, and CSB in increasing the quality and effective use of performance appraisal
3.1. Support Public Service Development Agency (PSDA) in elaborating methodological packages develop training packages and deliver trainings in line with the PAR Action Plan 3.2. Support PSDA in analyzing the legal framework related to design and delivery of public services and preparing the package of legislative changes 3.3. Support the Unified Service Center of the Ministry of Internal Affairs’ (MIA) Patrol Police Department in strengthening its organizational capacity through implementation of the Common Assessment Framework (CAF) and series of trainings, for effective delivery of customer-oriented disability inclusive public services 3.4. Support Digital Governance Agency (DGA) in developing the e-Governance Strategy 3.5 Continue supporting DGA in further digitization of services and their integration into My.gov.ge
4.1 Promote PAR-related activities of CSOs by providing grant focusing on priority areas such as gender in PAR, participation in policy-making and others

1.1. 90% of female and male civil servants from Policy Planning Units trained on policy planning, monitoring and evaluation from all line ministries; 80% of female and male civil servants attending the trainings demonstrated increase in knowledge 1.2. Three strategic documents are being drafted in line with the new policy standards - PAR Strategy 2021-2026 and its Action Plan, e-Governance Strategy 2021-2025 and its Action Plan, Maritime Transport Strategy 2021-2025 and its Action Plan 1.3. The project supported Administration of the Government of Georgia (AoG) to develop and finalize the concept of the M&E e-system together with the Digital Governance Agency (DGA) and through active participation of the line ministries. 1st phase of the government-wide M&E e-System is scheduled to be completed by March 2021
2.1. With the project support, CSB arranged 21 thematic Civil Servants’ Forum meetings attended by 1,388 female and male civil servants; 93% of the surveyed forum participants report the meetings as “useful”; 330 managers trained on Management and Leadership Skills 2.2./Electronic Human Resource Management System (eHRMS) is enhanced with 4 new fully operational modules 2.3. Accreditation process of basic mandatory training programs was further supported and nine training programs (both classroom and online) are accredited 2.4. Performance appraisal-related work in three line ministries (MoESD, MoHLSA, MEPA) and AoG is in active phase
3.1. Five methodological and training packages are developed and ready to use (costing, PwD inclusive service design and delivery, CAF, customer satisfaction) and more than 100 public servants from 10 different public agencies trained, using the developed material 3.2. Package of legislative changes on Public Services are elaborated 3.3. Capacity development initiative for the staff of the Patrol Police Unified Service Center of MIA including customer service and quality control, disability inclusive services and CAF is in active phase 3.4.Development of the e-Governance Strategy is ongoing 3.5. 37 new services were added to the Unified Service Portal My.gov.ge by DGA; in total 699 services are now available on the Portal, 133 with support of the PAR project; Compared to 2019, in 2020 uptake of e-services on My.gov.ge increased by 153%
4.1. CSO component was fine-tuned in response to COVID-19; three new research grants were initiated in thematic areas of PAR in the context of COVID-19 focusing on digital learning readiness assessment, challenges in provision of services to women victims of domestic violence by the Ministry of Internal Affairs during pandemic and compliance with public participation component in policy making; additionally two grants were provided to support development and deployment of Risk Communication Strategic Guidelines for public health emergencies and provision of professional home care services to elderly and vulnerable persons, as well as creation of Home Care (HC) online learning platform and adaptation HC mobile application

1.1 Support Administration of Georgia to develop Government-wide electronic performance tracking and evaluation system 1.2 Enhance capacity of policy support staff across all line ministries 2.1 Support introduction of civil service management system 2.2 Raise awareness on new law on Civil Service 2.3 Follow up introduction of change management approach 2.5 Number of projects supported by PAR offering targeted support to emerging needs 2.6 Identify Civil Society Organizations to be engaged in PAR implementation and/or monitoring 3.1 Support development of Unified Public Service Design and Delivery Standards 3.2-3.4 - Promote e-governance

Government has better methodological tools and civil servants are trained to plan, coordinate and monitor policy
1.1. A new Whole-of-Government policy making standards along with a detailed handbook on policy planning, monitoring and evaluation finalized. A concept of M&E system has been developed 1.2. Capacities of policy planning and coordination units in policy analysis have been increased
Civil servants experience tangible changes foreseen by the law on civil service, are able to better understand and contribute to the implementation process.
2.1. Awareness of line managers on the Law of Civil Service and all related novelties has been increased. Coordination of the implementation of the Law on Civil Service ensured via HR Forum meetings. 2.2. Capacities of managers to carry out performance evaluation of civil servants in nine ministries has been increased. 2.3. An accreditation system of mandatory training programs developed. Three training programs were accredited. 2.5. Emerging Needs: Three emerging needs’ initiatives focusing on: 1. Improving organisational structure, policy planning, and HR practices at the Ministry of Education, Culture and Sport of Ajara Autonomous Republic; 2. Improving Pest Management Service at National Food Agency and 3. Introducing Electronic Apostille Service at Public Service Development Agency have been supported. In addition, the project “Supporting the Ministry of Finance and Economy of Ajara to Improve Organizational Structure, Policy Planning and HR Practices” initiated in 2018 resulted in update of the organizational structure and functional and job descriptions of MoFEA, improvement of business processes, elaboration of one-year action plan and the department-level action plans, assessment of staff training needs, and creation of professional development planning system. 2.6. Further partnerships with four CSOs have been developed to build their capacity in PAR implementation and support smaller scale research initiatives on following pre-selected topics: a )Political Independence of Civil Servants and the role of a Senior Civil Servant; b) Perceptions and attitudes towards Performance Appraisal systems among civil servants; c) Exploration of the gender path of female and male civil servants in the Georgian civil service; d) Mapping of public services available for People with Disabilities (PwD), their needs assessment, and study of international practice.
Citizens benefit from better availability, accessibility and improved institutional resilience of electronic services.
3.1. Unified standards of Public Service Design and Delivery have been developed along with a policy document on Public Service Design and Delivery, major provisions of which were reflected in the PAR Action Plan 2019-2020, allowing implementation of the policy’s four streams: service design, service delivery, quality assurance and costing of services. Quality assurance tool (Common Assessment Framework - CAF) has been implemented in one of the key public service provider agencies: Public Service Hall. 3.2. Knowledge and expertise management in e-governance has improved. 3.3. Accessibility to Electronic services has increased: citizens’ usage of the portal My.gov.ge has been increasing steadily since 2012. During 2019, usage of e-services on the portal increased by about 50% as compared to the previous year (154,396) and reached 305,168. 34 additional public services have been added into the My.gov.ge portal by the Data Exchange Agency.
